Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Acupuncture for Pain Management in Surgical Oncology Patients Undergoing Thoracotomy

Trial_Design.evidence: 162 cancer patients scheduled for thoracotomy were randomised

Intervention.evidence: A) preoperative implantation of small intradermal needles retained for 4 weeks (intervention) or B) preoperative placement of sham needles (control)

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial investigated whether a specially developed acupuncture technique could reduce postoperative pain and analgesic use

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was pain intensity measured by the Brief Pain Inventory (BPI) at 30 days post-surgery

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was maintained for patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 81 participants were randomised to each group

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on [number analysed] using an intention-to-treat approach

Result_Outcome.evidence: At 30 days, there was no significant difference in BPI pain intensity scores between the intervention and control groups (mean difference = 0.05, 95% CI: -0.64 to 0.74; p=0.9)

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were not reported, indicating the safety of the intervention
